1.0     EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Affected employees will be consulted on the development and execution of this plan and all elements required by the PSM regulation. Affected employees will be provided access to all information developed. Specific participation requirements are listed in the sections that follow.


2.0     PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI)

2.1     Written information has been developed for processes covered by this regulation. The purpose of written process safety information is to enable all persons involved in operating the process to identify and fully understand the hazards posed by the process. The PSI will be completed for the support of and prior to conducting Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs), the development of operating procedures and the development or conduct of operator, maintenance and contractor training.

The Production, Environmen-tal Health & Safety, and Maintenance Departments will ensure that the information required by this section is up-to-date and made available to all affected employees.

2.2. The PSM Coordinator will ensure that necessary Process Safety Information is created or updated before PHA's e conducted. 

2.3    The PSM Coordinator will ensure the PSI is maintained current and made available to those developing, conducting and reviewing:

A. Site "What If" s.
 
B. Maintenance and operating procedures and training documents.
 
C. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).
 
D. Management of Change (MOC) activities.
 
E. Investigations. 
 
F. Contractor coordination.

2.4        The PSI package must be comprehensive to support an accurate assessment of potential fire and explosion hazards, reactivity hazards, safety and health issues for employees and any corrosion/erosion effects on process equipment and monitoring tools. PSI will include at least:

A.    Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for each hazardous chemical as required by the OSHA Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) regulation 1910.1200 and the site's written HAZCOM program. The site EH&S Manager or a designated individual will ensure that all required MSDSs are complete and available to all affected employees and contractors.

B.    Any necessary supplemental chemical information including chemical intermediates, over-pressure and runaway reaction hazards.

 C.        Information concerning the technology of the process. This information shall include at least the following:

1. A block flow that illustrates the major process equipment and interconnecting process flow lines.
2. Process chemistry.
3. Maximum intended inventory for process chemicals.
4. Safe upper and lower limits for temperatures, pressures, flows, and compositions (limits beyond which would be considered safety upset conditions).
5. A qualitative estimate of the consequences of deviations that could occur if operating beyond the established process limits, including safety and health effects on affected personnel.

D.    Process equipment information shall be documented in the PSI package including:

1. Materials of construction.
 
2. Piping and instrument diagrams (P&ID's) used to describe the relationships between equipment and instrumentation. P&ID's will include this and other relevant information including:

A. The information for the piping designer and engineering staff. 
B. Main flow streams including valves. 
C. Pressures and temperatures on all feed and product lines within all major vessels and in and out of headers and heat exchangers.
D. Points of pressure and temperature control.
E. Construction materials.
F. Pump capacities and pressure heads. 
G. Compressor horsepower. 
H. Vessel design pressures and temperatures.
I. Major control loops.
J. Key utilities.

3. Electrical classifications.
4. Relief system design documentation and the design basis.
5. Ventilation system design.
6. Documented codes and standards used or relied upon in the design of the process equipment.
7. Material and energy balances (for processes built after May 26, 1992).
8. Safety systems (interlocks, detection and suppression systems).
9. Documentation shall include that the process equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.
10. For existing equipment designed and built to codes no longer in general use, the Glens Falls Engineering Staff  will determine and document that the equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and operated in a safe manner.


 3.0    PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

3.1     The "What If" Analysis has been selected as the appropriate process hazard analysis methodology for Tenneco Packaging - NAPP, Glens Falls.

3.2 The Site Manager and PSM Coordinator will assure that PHA's are conducted initially and when changes in the covered process warrant revisions. 

3.3     The Site Manager and PSM Coordinator will also assure that the PHA is updated and revalidated at least every five years.

3.4     The PSM Coordinator will ensure the following information is provided, as a minimum, to the Hazard study team:

A.    The PSI package (section 4 above).

B.    Any previous incident(s) which had a potential for catastrophic consequences in the workplace.

3.5     The PSM Coordinator will ensure that issues raised by the PHA are reported  and corrective action plans with completion schedules are available to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. 

3.6     All PHA reports, corrective action plans and schedules, will be retained by the Glens Falls PSM Coordinator for the life of the process.


4.0 OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPs)

4.1     Glens Falls employees will create, implement and maintain written SOPs that provide clear instruction to safely conduct process operations consistent with the process safety information and shall address at least the following elements.

    The Production department has implemented written operat-ing procedures that provide instruction to safely conduct process operations consistent with the process safety information.   The procedures shall be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the process. The procedures include:

A. Steps for each operating phase;

(i) Start-up under normal operations, experimental runs, turn around or emergency situations;

(ii) Normal operation and shutdown;

(iii) Temporary operations.

B. Operating Limits:

(i) Consequences of deviation; and

(ii) Steps required to correct or avoid deviation.

 

C. Safety and health considerations:

(i) Properties of, and hazard presented by, the chemicals used in the process;

(ii) Precautions necessary to prevent exposure including engineering controls, administrative controls, and personal protective equipment;

(iii) Control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs;

(iv) Quality control for raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and

(v) Any special or unique hazards.

D. Safety systems and their functions.

4.2     SOP content will be reviewed by, affected employees, site engineering staff, Foam Unit Manager and EH&S Manager, prior to finalizing any procedure.

4.3     The procedures shall be readily accessible to all employees or contractors who work in or maintain the process.

4.4     Operating procedures shall be reviewed and updated as often as necessary to ensure that they reflect current operating practice. Procedures will be updated when there is a change in the chemicals, technology, equipment or facilities used in the process as required by Management of Change.

4.5     All procedures will be revalidated and approved to be current and accurate, at least once per year by plant maintenance/ operations.

4.6     Operations and Maintenance supervision shall implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations. These include, but are not limited to, energy control procedures (Lockout/Tagout, Electrical Safety, opening process equipment or piping), Confined Space Entry, and other safety requirements.

 5.0 TRAINING

5.1     The responsible department manager will implement training for each covered process (or extrusion line) when the PSI, SOPs or other required information is different from another process or line.

5.2    Personnel operating the process will demonstrate  understanding of SOPs and knowledge in the operations of the process.      

5.3    Newly assigned employees and contractors will be trained in an overview of the process and the operating procedures. An emphasis shall be placed on the specific hazards and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job task.  

    5.4    Refresher training shall be provided to each employee involved in operating a process, as often as necessary, to assure the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.

5.5    Employees and contractors will be trained as the initial or revised training becomes available.

5.6    Training will be reviewed and revised as often as necessary by department managers to ensure that training is accurate and reflects current requirements. Training will be reviewed as follows:
A.    Yearly to ensure the necessary skills, knowledge and routines are being properly understood, implemented and producing the desired results.  
B.    When there are changes in the process safety information or operating procedures.
C.     When training evaluations indicate a need for revision.

5.7    Supplemental training shall be provided to each employee or contractor involved in operating or maintaining the covered process(es) at least every three years to assure that each employee or contractor understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.

5.8     Supplemental training shall also be conducted per the Operator training procedures when changes are made to the process to ensure the changes and effects on the job tasks are understood.


5.9     Documentation of initial, supplemental and refresher training shall be forwarded to Human Resources Department for record keeping. Training shall be documented in writing with the inclusion of:
- the employee's name
- trainer's signature or initials
- dates of training


 6.0  MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Management of Change is the system required to be implemented for any changes (other than replacements-in-kind") that affect any portion of the PSI, SOPs or facilities that affect any covered process(es). 
The Management of Change procedure will be initiated and approved prior to implementing any changes being introduced or introducing any new chemicals to the process. 


7.0.  PRE-START UP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)

7.1     PSSRs will be performed on all new facilities and when modifications require a change in the process safety information prior to the introduction of any highly hazardous chemicals to the process.

7.2     The review shall confirm that:

A. A "WHAT IF" study has been performed on new facilities in accordance the provisions of PSM Section 10 - Management of Change

B.    Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

C.    ALL PSI, safety, operating, maintenance, safe practices and emergency procedures are developed, evaluated and adequate for use.

D.    ALL training is completed.


8.0  MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

8.1    This procedure categorizes maintenance into two areas: scheduled and unscheduled maintenance. Work performed through the preventive maintenance schedule or projects is scheduled maintenance.   Work performed as the result of a breakdown is unscheduled maintenance. 

8.2     This section applies to the following process equipment:

A. Pressure vessels and storage tanks.
 
B. Piping systems (including components such as valves).
 
C. Relief and vent systems and devices.
 
D. Emergency shutdown systems.
 
E. Controls including monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks.
 
F. Pumps.

8.3 SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE:
Weekly/Monthly Preventive Maintenance (PM) Lists and Projects are used to schedule maintenance, improvements or calibration of manufacturing equipment or support equipment.


 9.0 CONTRACTORS

9.1  This section applies to contractors performing maintenance, repair, major renovations or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  

9.2     A contractor's safety performance and programs will be evaluated by the project manager as a part of the contractor selection process.  

9.3     The appropriate project manager shall advise the contract supervisor of the known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards related to the scope of work and the process. Any hazards presented by contractor work will also be addressed.

9.4     The appropriate project manager will ensure the contractors are instructed in the applicable safe work practices and emergency action plans.

9.5     The project manager shall periodically evaluate the performance of contractors and ensure the provisions of the Tenneco Packaging - NAPP Contractor Compliance with Safety and Health Rules are being fulfilled.

9.6     Contractor access to the plant and operating units will be controlled by the project manager


10.0     EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

Emergency planning and response will be in accordance with the requirements of the Tenneco Packaging-NAPP, Glens Falls site Emergency Plan.


11.0         INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS

11.1     All incidents involving an event that resulted in or could have resulted in a release of a highly hazardous chemical, serious injury or property damage will be investigated per the Tenneco Packaging-NAPP, Glens Falls plant Incident Investigation Process and Incident Reporting Procedures.

11.2     All investigation findings, corrective actions and corrective action schedules will be available to affected employees and contractors. 

 12.0 COMPLIANCE AUDITS

12.1    A compliance audit will be conducted and documented at least every two years.

12.2     The PSM Coordinator, or designate, will assure the audit is conducted by knowledgeable persons responsible for the performance of this regulation.

12.3     A report will be issued detailing the findings. A plan will be developed to address the findings, corrective action will be scheduled and tracked to completion.

12.4    The final report, corrective action and schedules will be shared with the affected employees and contractors. 

12.5     The site EH&S department shall retain at least the most recent compliance audit reports along with corrective action schedules and closure documentation.

13.0   REVIEW/REVISION

13.1     This plan will be reviewed periodically by the PSM Coordinator or other designated persons. Revisions will be presented to the site management staff for approval.

13.2     Significant revisions will be reviewed with affected employees per Section 1.0 of this procedure.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
 
 Tenneco is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. The NAPP division of 
Tenneco has aggressive environmental and safety goals. Corporate EH&S personnel assist 
facilities in developing programs to meet these goals. The Glens Falls facility has an EH&S 
Manager to coordinate safety and environmental programs.
 
 This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that 
covers design, installation, operation, maintenance and training for processes at the Glens Falls 
facility.  In the event any unforeseeable release might still occur, the facility coordinates 
emergency response primarily with local fire departments. The Warren County LEPC is also made 
aware of our storage of flammable substances.
 
2. GLENS FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED
 
 The Glens Falls facility manufactures packaging materials including padded mailers, polyethylene 
foam in the form of sheets and planks and polyethylene bubble. The foam process uses a 
regulated flammable gas as a blowing agent. The maximum inventory at the facility is about 
68,000 pounds. The maximum in one tank is about 48,000 pounds. The remainder is located in 
smaller tanks several hundred feet from the larger tank.
 
3. THE WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SECNARIO 
 
 The scenarios for Glens Falls are taken from the EPA's RMP Guidance for propane storage 
facilities because the regulated flammable gas stored in Glens Falls is very similar to propane.
 
 The worst case scenario submitted for a level 3 flammable substance involves catastrophic 
release from a storage tank. Our scenario is based on a maximum, one tank storage of 48,000 
pounds. Passive mitigation systems have not been considered. It is assumed the entire contents 
are released as a vapor cloud and 10% of the cloud ignites in a vapor cloud explosion. This 
produces off-site
 consequences of a magnitude of one poun

d overpressure up to 0.3 miles from the tank.
 
 The alternate release scenario submitted for a level 3 flammable substance involves a spill of 
flammable material, such as from overfilling the storage tank. The scenario assumes release of 
9700 pounds of flammable material which is assumed to produce a pool fire. The guidance 
document indicates the maximum distance for people to suffer second degree burns from a 40 
second exposure is 0.1 miles from the center of the pool.
 
4. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC 
PREVENTION STEPS
 
 The Glens Falls facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release 
prevention requirements contained in 40CFR part 68. In addition, the Glens Falls foam process is 
subject to the requirements of 29CFR1910.119. The facility has also submitted a Title V air 
permit application. The elements of the Glens Falls program follow closely those contained in the 
PSM regulation. A brief description follows:
 
 Process Safety Information
 The facility maintains a detailed record of process safety information that describes chemical 
hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the covered process.
 
 Process Hazard Analysis
 In order to identify and then control the hazards of the process, the Glens Falls facility has 
performed a What-If, HAZOP analysis using a team of qualified people with expertise in 
engineering, process operations and a leader with hazard analysis expertise. The hazard review is 
updated at least every 5 years or when major changes are made. The findings are addressed in a 
timely manner and documented.
 
 Operating Procedures
 To ensure the covered process is operated safely, written operating instructions are developed, 
maintained, and made readily available to operators. These procedures address various modes of 
operation such as startup, shutdown, normal operation, temporary operations, emergency 
shutdown and emergency operation.

Training
 The Glens Falls facility trains employees that operate the covered processes initially, as changes 
are made and refresher training is conducted at least every three years. Training records are 
maintained.
 
 Mechanical Integrity
 The Glens Falls maintenance personnel perform documented maintenance on covered process 
equipment to ensure proper operation. A list of critical equipment with required test frequencies 
is maintained. Identified deficiencies are corrected in a timely manner. The work is performed by 
trained maintenance personnel. Equipment covered includes storage tanks, piping systems, relief 
and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.
 
 Management of Change
 Written Management of change procedures are followed, covering changes to process 
chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Operating and maintenance personnel 
affected by changes made aware of the changes and retrained as needed.
 
 Pre-startup Safety Reviews
 These reviews are conducted for initial startups and those following modifications. The reviews 
confirm that construction, equipment and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for 
a safe startup prior to placing the equipment into operation.
 
 Compliance Audits
 Audits will continue be done to ensure that the provisions of PSM and RPM are being 
implemented. Any necessary corrective actions are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.
 
 Incident Investigation
 Tenneco personnel will promptly investigate any incident that has or could reasonable have 
resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. The investigations seek to identify 
causes and any corrective actions that may be implemented to prevent recurrences. Reports will 
be maintained for at least 5 years.
 
 
 Employee Participation
 Tenneco believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. 
Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention

issues 
through frequent safety meetings, safety committees and incentive programs. PSM information,  
including PHA's, as well as operating procedures, are readily available to affected employees.
 
 Contractors
 The facility occasionally uses outside contractors to perform specialized maintenance or 
construction activities. A written contractor safety program is followed that includes a safety 
performance evaluation prior to contract, a review of the hazards the contractor may encounter 
from the covered process, safety rules to be followed and emergency response procedures.
 
5. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
 
 There have been no significant accidental releases from the covered process during the past five 
years at the Glens Falls facility.
 
6. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
 
 The facility maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with potential accidents related 
to the covered process. The plan includes first aid response, notification of emergency 
responders and evacuation. Tenneco employees do not directly respond to incidents such as 
fires beyond the incipient stage. The emergency response plan is communicated to employees 
and updated as needed.
 
7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Tenneco involves all employees in managing safety by setting aggressive goals, conducting 
frequent safety meetings and training, forming safety teams, enforcing safety rules and 
rewarding the meeting of goals.
